consequences if petition does not lapse bankruptcy act 1966 s.52 federal court of australia act 1976 ss.5 , 25 bankruptcy
creditor's petition
sequestration order made on the creditor's petition set aside by the high court
whether creditor's petition had lapsed pursuant to s 52(4)
stated case

federal court of australia act 1976 (cth), s 25(6). held (per curiam), that the making of a sequestration order on a creditor's petition within twelve months of the date of presentation of the petition will prevent a creditor's petition from lapsing under s 52(4) of the bankruptcy act 1966 even if that sequestration order is subsequently set aside as beyond power by order of a superior court of record. such setting aside does not mean that the sequestration order was a nullity but merely voidable. to hold otherwise would give debtors undesirable immunity in respect of a particular petition possibly with important consequences in respect of the commencement of the bankruptcy and the assets available for distribution to creditors.

citances.sentence: The debate as to whether the reference to "application" includes reference to an invalid application has similarities in other areas, for example, in an entirely different context: Adams v Lambert [2006] FCA 623 at [10] .
